answer_html: Since \(252 \pi\) is roughly equal to \(800\), we can say that the Bubble Nebula is expanding at a rate of approximatively 8(1034) km3/h.Fun Fact: For info, the volume of the Earth is roughly 1012 km3 and the Sun’s volume is roughly 1018 km3.

Since $252 \pi$ is roughly equal to $800$, we can say that the Bubble

hints_html: We are told the rate at which the radius of a sphere is changing and asked to find the rate at which the volume is changing. How can we use the volume equation provided to relate the rates?
hints_latex:
We are told the rate at which the radius of a sphere is changing and
asked to find the rate at which the volume is changing. How can we use
the volume equation provided to \textbf{relate} the rates?
hints_raw: We are told the rate at which the radius of a sphere is changing and asked to find the rate at which the volume is changing.  How can we use the volume equation provided to '''relate''' the rates?
sols_html:
Since we are interested in the rate of change of the volume of the sphere while being given information about the rate of change of its radius we are facing a typical related rates problem.

There are two variables here at stake: the radius of the sphere, \(r\), and its volume, \(V\). Now there isn’t ONE sphere, since the sphere is expanding with time. This means that actually, both the radius and the volume are actually functions of time that we can write \(r(t)\) and \(V(t)\).

We know the relationship that exists between the volume and the radius and a sphere, which at any time \(t\) is expressed by the equation

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle V(t) = \frac{4}{3} \pi (r(t))^3\end{aligned}\]

Since we are interested in the relationship that links the rates of change with respect of time for both the radius and the volume of the sphere, it makes sense to differentiate this equation on both sides with respect to time. We obtain:

\[\begin{aligned} V'(t) &= \frac{4}{3} \pi \cdot 3(r(t))^2 \cdot r'(t) \\ &= 4\pi (r(t))^2 \cdot r'(t)\end{aligned}\]

Now the problem tells us that there is a specific time, let’s call it \(t_0\), at which we know both the radius of the sphere and its instantaneous rate of change. In other words, if we use the data given in the statement of the problem, we have:

  • \(r(t_0) = 3 \cdot 10^{13}\)

  • \(r'(t_0) = 7 \cdot 10^6\)

And we are interested in obtaining the rate of change of volume at that moment, that is \(V'(t_0)\). So we can use the equation we obtained above at the time \(t_0\), substitute the available information and obtain that:

\[\begin{aligned} V'(t_0) &= 4\pi (r(t_0))^2 \cdot r'(t_0) \\ &= 4\pi (3 \cdot 10^{13})^2 \cdot 7 \cdot 10^6 \\ &= 4\pi \cdot 9 \cdot 10^{26} \cdot 7 \cdot 10^6 \\ &= 4\cdot 7 \cdot 9 \cdot \pi \cdot 10^{32} \\ &= 252\pi \cdot 10^{32}\end{aligned}\]

Since \(252 \pi\) is roughly equal to \(800\), we can say that the Bubble Nebula is expanding at a rate of approximatively 8(1034) km3/h.

Fun Fact: For info, the volume of the Earth is roughly 1012 km3 and the Sun’s volume is roughly 1018 km3.
sols_latex:
Since we are interested in the rate of change of the volume of the
sphere while being given information about the rate of change of its
radius we are facing a typical related rates problem.

There are two variables here at stake: the radius of the sphere, $r$,
and its volume, $V$. Now there isn't ONE sphere, since the sphere is
expanding with time. This means that actually, both the radius and the
volume are actually functions of time that we can write $r(t)$ and
$V(t)$.

We know the relationship that exists between the volume and the radius
and a sphere, which at any time $t$ is expressed by the equation

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
V(t) = \frac{4}{3} \pi (r(t))^3
\end{align*}

Since we are interested in the relationship that links the rates of
change with respect of time for both the radius and the volume of the
sphere, it makes sense to differentiate this equation on both sides with
respect to time. We obtain:

\begin{align*}
V'(t) &= \frac{4}{3} \pi \cdot 3(r(t))^2 \cdot r'(t) \\
&= 4\pi (r(t))^2 \cdot r'(t)
\end{align*}

Now the problem tells us that there is a specific time, let's call it
$t_0$, at which we know both the radius of the sphere and its
instantaneous rate of change. In other words, if we use the data given
in the statement of the problem, we have:

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $r(t_0) = 3 \cdot 10^{13}$
\item
  $r'(t_0) = 7 \cdot 10^6$
\end{itemize}

And we are interested in obtaining the rate of change of volume at that
moment, that is $V'(t_0)$. So we can use the equation we obtained above
at the time $t_0$, substitute the available information and obtain that:

\begin{align*}
V'(t_0) &= 4\pi (r(t_0))^2 \cdot r'(t_0) \\
&= 4\pi (3 \cdot 10^{13})^2 \cdot 7 \cdot 10^6 \\
&= 4\pi \cdot 9 \cdot 10^{26} \cdot 7 \cdot 10^6 \\
&= 4\cdot 7 \cdot 9 \cdot \pi \cdot 10^{32} \\
&= 252\pi \cdot 10^{32}
\end{align*}

Since $252 \pi$ is roughly equal to $800$, we can say that the Bubble
Nebula is expanding at a rate of approximatively
8(10\textsuperscript{34}) km\textsuperscript{3}/h.

Fun Fact: For info, the volume of the Earth is roughly
10\textsuperscript{12} km\textsuperscript{3} and the Sun's volume is
roughly 10\textsuperscript{18} km\textsuperscript{3}.
sols_raw:
Since we are interested in the rate of change of the volume of the sphere while being given information about the rate of change of its radius we are facing a typical related rates problem.

There are two variables here at stake: the radius of the sphere, <math>r</math>, and its volume, <math>V</math>. Now there isn't ONE sphere, since the sphere is expanding with time. This means that actually, both the radius and the volume are actually functions of time that we can write <math>r(t)</math> and <math>V(t)</math>.

We know the relationship that exists between the volume and the radius and a sphere, which at any time <math>t</math> is expressed by the equation
:<math>\displaystyle
V(t) = \frac{4}{3} \pi (r(t))^3
</math>

Since we are interested in the relationship that links the rates of change with respect of time for both the radius and the volume of the sphere, it makes sense to differentiate this equation on both sides with respect to time. We obtain:
:<math>\begin{align}
V'(t) &= \frac{4}{3} \pi \cdot 3(r(t))^2 \cdot r'(t) \\
&= 4\pi (r(t))^2 \cdot r'(t)
\end{align}
</math>

Now the problem tells us that there is a specific time, let's call it <math>t_0</math>, at which we know both the radius of the sphere and its instantaneous rate of change. In other words, if we use the data given in the statement of the problem, we have:
* <math>r(t_0) = 3 \cdot 10^{13}</math>
* <math>r'(t_0) = 7 \cdot 10^6</math>

And we are interested in obtaining the rate of change of volume at that moment, that is <math>V'(t_0)</math>. So we can use the equation we obtained above at the time <math>t_0</math>, substitute the available information and obtain that:
:<math>\begin{align}
V'(t_0) &= 4\pi (r(t_0))^2 \cdot r'(t_0) \\
&= 4\pi (3 \cdot 10^{13})^2 \cdot 7 \cdot 10^6 \\
&= 4\pi \cdot 9 \cdot 10^{26} \cdot 7 \cdot 10^6 \\
&= 4\cdot 7 \cdot 9 \cdot \pi \cdot 10^{32} \\
&= 252\pi \cdot 10^{32}
\end{align}
</math>

Since <math>252 \pi</math> is roughly equal to <math>800</math>, we can say that the Bubble Nebula is expanding at a rate of approximatively 8(10<sup>34</sup>) km<sup>3</sup>/h.

Fun Fact: For info, the volume of the Earth is roughly 10<sup>12</sup> km<sup>3</sup> and the Sun's volume is roughly 10<sup>18</sup> km<sup>3</sup>.
statement_html:
The Bubble Nebula is an expanding sphere of gas and stellar ejecta in the constellation Cassiopeia.

The radius of the Bubble Nebula is 3(1013) km, and it is expanding at a rate of 7(106) km/h. Determine how quickly the volume of the nebula is increasing.

Hint: the volume of a sphere of radius r is”(4/3)\(\pi\)r3
statement_latex:
The \emph{Bubble Nebula} is an expanding sphere of gas and stellar
ejecta in the constellation Cassiopeia.

The radius of the Bubble Nebula is 3(10\textsuperscript{13}) km, and it
is expanding at a rate of 7(10\textsuperscript{6}) km/h. Determine how
quickly the volume of the nebula is increasing.

Hint: the volume of a sphere of radius \emph{r} is''(4/3)$\pi$r\textsuperscript{3}
statement_raw:
The ''Bubble Nebula'' is an expanding sphere of gas and stellar ejecta in the constellation Cassiopeia.

The radius of the Bubble Nebula is 3(10<sup>13</sup>) km, and it is expanding at a rate of 7(10<sup>6</sup>) km/h. Determine how quickly the volume of the nebula is increasing.

Hint: the volume of a sphere of radius ''r'' is ''(4/3)&pi;r<sup>3</sup>
